questions.question:
Which of the following languages is (are) non-regular?
\(L_1 = \{0^m1^n \mid 0 \leq m \leq n \leq 10000\}\)
\(L_2 = \{w \mid w\) reads the same forward and backward\(\}\)
\(L_3 = \{w \in \{0, 1\} ^* \mid w\) contains an even number of 0's and an even number of 1's\(\}\)


(GATE IT 2008)
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Consider a CFG with the following productions.

\(S \to AA \mid B\)
\(A \to 0A \mid A0 \mid 1\)
\(B \to 0B00 \mid 1\)

S is the start symbol, A and B are non-terminals and 0 and 1 are the terminals. The language generated by this grammar is:

(GATE IT 2008)
options:
D.

The set of all strings over \(\{0, 1\}\) containing at least two 0's
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Consider the following languages.
\(L_1 = \{a^i b^j c^k \mid i = j, k \geq 1\}\)
\(L_2 = \{a^i b^j \mid j = 2i, i \geq 0\}\)
Which of the following is true?

(GATE IT 2008)
options:
A.

\(L_1\) is not a CFL but \(L_2\) is

C.

\(L_1 \cup L_2\) is not a CFL but \(L_2\) is

D.

There is a 4-state PDA that accepts \(L_1\), but there is no DPDA that accepts \(L_2\).
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
If the final states and non-final states in the DFA below are interchanged, then which of the following languages over the alphabet {a,b} will be accepted by the new DFA?



(GATE IT 2008)
options:
A.

Set of all strings that do not end with ab

B.

Set of all strings that begin with either a or ab

C.

Set of all strings that do not contain the substring ab,

D.

The set described by the regular expression b*aa*(ba)*b*
questions.correct_answer:
A.

Set of all strings that do not end with ab
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Which of the following are regular sets?

\(I. \{a^{n}b^{2m}|n\geq 0,m\geq 0\} \)
II. \( \{a^{n}b^{m}|n=2m\} \)
III. \(\{a^{n}b^{m}|n\neq m\} \)
IV. \(\{xcy|x,y,\in \{a,b\}^*\}\)

(GATE CSE 2008)

1. \(\epsilon\) + 0(01*1 + 00) * 01*
2. \(\epsilon\) + 0(10 *1 + 00) * 0
3. \(\epsilon\) + 0(10 *1 + 10) *1
4. \(\epsilon\) + 0(10 *1 + 10) *10 *

questions.question:
Which of the following statements are true?

I. Every left-recursive grammar can be converted to a right-recursive grammar and vice-versa

II. All \(\varepsilon\)-productions can be removed from any context-free grammar by suitable transformations

III. The language generated by a context-free grammar all of whose productions are of the form x \(\rightarrow\) w or x \(\rightarrow\) wY (where, w is a string of terminals and Y is a non-terminal), is always regular

IV. The derivation trees of strings generated by a context-free grammar in Chomsky Normal Form are always binary trees

(GATE CSE 2008)
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Which of the following statements is false?

(GATE CSE 2008)
options:
A.

Every NFA can be converted to an equivalent DFA

B.

Every non-deterministic Turing machine can be converted to an equivalent deterministic Turing machine

C.

Every regular language is also a context-free language

D.

Every subset of a recursively enumerable set is recursive
questions.correct_answer:
D.

Every subset of a recursively enumerable set is recursive

questions.question:
Which of the following are decidable?

I. Whether the intersection of two regular languages is infinite
II. Whether a given context-free language is regular
III. Whether two push-down automata accept the same language
IV. Whether a given grammar is context-free

(GATE CSE 2008)

questions.question:
Which of the following is true for the language{ \(a^{p}\)|p is a prime} ?

(GATE CSE 2008)
options:
A.

It is not accepted by a Turing Machine

D.

It is neither regular nor context-free, but accepted by a Turing machine
questions.correct_answer:
D.

It is neither regular nor context-free, but accepted by a Turing machine
